evidence_disclaimer: Of 48 body-type x principle predictions, only 3 have direct empirical evidence. 45 are estimated from first principles. Confidence: 1-2/5 unless noted.

petite.key_feature: Short total vertical extent; all proportions compressed

tall.key_feature: Long vertical extent; high natural proportion ratio

inverted_triangle.key_feature: Shoulders wider than hips; V-shaped torso

plus_size.key_feature: W:H in Ashida reversal zone (>0.52); ALL shapes exist within plus-size

note_plus_size: Plus size is NOT a shape — it's a size range that intersects ALL shapes. Effects depend on BOTH shape AND size.

modifiers.notes: Lower W:H on average. BUT shorter torso may have fewer visible stripes, reducing Oppel-Kundt contribution.
Same absolute edge contraction = larger % on smaller body.
GR break at 38.2% already near natural waist for many petite women. Provides no corrective illusion.
Focal points at neckline draw eye up. Low-placed focal points anchor eye down, emphasizing short stature.
HVI more valuable on shorter bodies; each % height increase has larger relative impact. 5% on 155cm = 7.8cm gain.
STRONGEST single recommendation for petite. 12-15% ML elongation visually lengthens proportionally shorter upper body. Combined with HVI: 10-18% upper torso elongation.
Loose creates 'drowning in fabric' effect (+3-6% widening). Garment-to-body-size ratio is LARGEST for petite.
Lower W:H; more visible stripes on longer torso (closer to optimal 8-12 count).
Same edge contraction on larger width = smaller %.
GR break at 38.2% may fall BELOW natural waist, shortening perceived legs. Need target ratio 0.33-0.35.
More 'garment real estate' for strategic placement. Less vulnerable to harmful focal points.
Don't need height illusion. Diminishing returns. Horizontal elements more useful if wanting to appear less tall.
Works normally. Additional height minimal relative to already-tall stature.
Both fitted and loose work. Most forgiving canvas for fit experimentation.
CRITICAL: hip zone W:H may exceed 0.52 crossover. Single H-striped garment covering both zones SLIMS upper body but may WIDEN lower body — amplifies exact imbalance.
Edge contraction stronger at narrow waist, weaker at wide hips. Dark colors slim waist more than hips IN %, partially correcting pear imbalance.
GR break at waist emphasizes width transition zone. Attention conflict at hip transition.
Bright belts/pockets at hip level increase fixation +15-25% -> +6-10% perceived hip width. MOST COMMON styling error for pears.
Vertical lines on LOWER body maximally useful (elongate legs, reduce hip width via height-width reciprocity). Princess seams through hip zone ideal.
Dual benefit: ML elongation + gaze redirection away from hips. BUT narrow V on small upper body may amplify shoulder-hip imbalance.
The most universally given pear advice and one of the few aligned with research. Leverages attention redirection + Cundall & Guo gaze-shift.
Apple midsection W:H 0.50-0.65 is IN Ashida crossover zone. NEVER recommend H-stripes across apple midsection for slimming.
No crossover for luminance. Dark colors work where stripes fail. MOST RELIABLE slimming tool for apple.
GR break at natural waist hits WIDEST zone. Belt/seam at GR = focal point at widest circumference. Shift above waist or eliminate.
Belts/seams at natural waist concentrate +10-20% additional fixation at widest zone. V-necklines and shoulder details draw eye ABOVE midsection.
Unbroken vertical from chest through hip bypasses midsection (eye follows PAST concern zone). BUT 4+ vertical lines trigger Oppel-Kundt. 1-2 seams: beneficial. 8+: harmful.
V elongates and redirects eye from midsection. BUT deep V on larger bust (common with apple) triggers FC-7A. Moderate depth optimal (30-50 degree).
Too tight: strain lines create widening. Too loose: tent/A-line widens silhouette. Semi-fitted (2-4cm ease) or empire waistline optimal.
THREE different W:H ratios (waist narrow, bust/hip wider). H-stripes may slim waist while having reduced/no effect at bust/hip. Net ambiguous.
Dark makes ALL edges contract equally. More benefit at narrow waist (larger %) than wider bust/hips -> reduces waist-to-hip differential. Suboptimal if goal is emphasize curves.
Waist IS narrowest point. GR break at waist emphasizes curve differential. This is the body type the rule was designed for.
Drawing attention to narrow waist makes flattering feature more prominent. Belts, nipped construction work well.
Strong verticals create straight channel contradicting in-out-in silhouette. Desirable for slimming, undesirable for celebrating shape.
V frames bust and emphasizes upper curve. V-shape echoes natural V from shoulder to waist. May emphasize bust more than some users want.
Fitted SHOWCASES natural curves. Loose HIDES defining feature (waist). Hourglass is the one body type where fitted is almost always optimal.
Within Helmholtz zone. Uniform width = uniform effect. Body type where generic stripe advice is MOST likely correct.
Uniform width = uniform % reduction. Straightforward.
GR break creates APPEARANCE of waist through proportion illusion. Higher weight potentially than other body types (more corrective work).
Single focal point at waist can CREATE waist definition. Peplum, contoured seaming, belt creates illusion of curves.
Uniform width means consistent HVI effect. Standard scoring.
V creates tapered angular line on otherwise-straight body. Converging lines create illusion of upper-body taper rectangle lacks.
Neither pure fitted nor pure loose helps. Need STRUCTURED garments that engineer curves (peplums, belted, darted).

modifiers.direction: transition at shoulders, slimming at hips
modifiers.notes: OPPOSITE of pear. H-stripes at shoulder zone may WIDEN already-wide shoulders.
More benefit at wide shoulders (larger absolute contraction) and larger % at narrower hips. Slightly reduces shoulder-to-hip differential.
GR break at waist creates anchor below widest point (shoulders). Better to use break at high hip to broaden perceived lower body.
Shoulder pads, boat necks, bright upper-body colors amplify fixation on already-wide upper body. Hip-level details, bold-colored bottoms draw gaze DOWN.
Vertical lines on upper body slim widest zone. On lower body less useful (hips don't need narrowing). Selective placement.
V narrows chin-to-neckline axis, making inverted triangle look MORE top-heavy. Better: boat neck or square neck to widen horizontal at neckline level.
Fitted bottom + relaxed top. Loose top softens wide shoulders; fitted/voluminous bottom adds weight to narrow lower body.
Firmly in Ashida reversal zone (W:H 0.55-0.80+). H-stripes produce OPPOSITE of intended effect. Popular wisdom is CORRECT here but for wrong reasons.
Same absolute edge contraction on much wider body = smaller %. Dark colors LESS effective in % for larger bodies — OPPOSITE of fashion advice. Still no reversal.
Like apple, natural waist may be widest circumference. GR target should shift based on actual thinnest-point ratio.
Cundall & Guo UK16+: loose redirects gaze from waist-hip to legs (-15% fixation shift -> ~1 dress size underestimation). DIRECT EVIDENCE.
1-2 princess seams: slimming (-2-4%). 4+: transition. 8-12+: Oppel-Kundt widening dominates. Pinstripe advice for plus-size may be HARMFUL.
V-elongation valuable. But FC-7A (deep V on wide chest) and FC-7C (gap on loose garments) both more likely. Moderate V-depth (40-60 degree) on semi-fitted garments.
Cundall & Guo UK16+: loose -> gaze redirection -> 1 dress size underestimation (-5-8%). ONLY body type with strong direct evidence for fit recommendations.

danger_zone_summary.alternative: H-stripes upper body ONLY; solid/dark lower body

danger_zone_summary.never_recommend: Belts/horizontal breaks at natural waist; H-stripes across midsection
danger_zone_summary.why: Focal point + stripe reversal at widest zone
danger_zone_summary.alternative: Empire line; unbroken vertical continuity through midsection

danger_zone_summary.never_recommend: H-stripes on upper body; shoulder pads; boat necks
danger_zone_summary.alternative: V-necklines with caution; dark/plain upper body; volume on lower body

danger_zone_summary.never_recommend: H-stripes for 'slimming'; pinstripes (many verticals); fitted garments
danger_zone_summary.why: H-stripes reverse; too many verticals reverse via Oppel-Kundt; fitted increases fixation
danger_zone_summary.alternative: Dark colors; 1-2 structural vertical lines; loose to semi-fitted

danger_zone_summary.never_recommend: Oversized/loose garments; low-placed focal points; wide horizontal stripes
danger_zone_summary.why: Garment overwhelms body; focal points anchor eye down; wide stripes reduce count below optimal
Hides defining feature (waist); flattens natural curve
